channel.title: Multiple forums, one database?
channel.description:
Well, I'm kind of new to MySQL, but I understand that you can have multiple SMF forums, for example, residing on one database as long as they have different prefixes, like forum1_ and forum2_.
My question is, how many can you put on a single database? Is there a difference in speed if you had each forum, say 5 of them, on separate databases, or should they all be on one? It's not a question of if I have enough databases, I'm hosting my own webserver, but rather the toll on the SQL querier/program/service/whatever if they are all in the same database or in separate ones.

item.title: Multiple forums, one database?
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

ThugLife:

Thats what i get for just reading the first 2 lines of the question >.O

item.title: Multiple forums, one database?
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“ThugLife, post:8, topic:138116”]I will try explain this as best i can, this way is very long but it seems to work good enough for me

First, install two one with the prefix smf_ and the second with the prefix smf1_ on the SAME database.
Then go into the second forums file, and go into you’re Sources folder and go into each file and search for
[php]{$db_prefix}members[/php]
and replace with
[php]smf_members[/php]
do that for every file in the sources folder.

That shares the members table, you can do it with other things just do the same but search for
[php]{$db_prefix}tablename[/php]
and replace with
[php]smf_tablename[/php]
some other tables you might want to share is karma so it would be [php]{$db_prefix}karma[/php]
just search around for table names you want to share, pretty simple but takes AGES.[/quote]

I wasn’t asking how to split it like MITB and Moparscape.org, I was asking if having too many forums on the same database would be slower than just having them on separate databases lol.

And some other people above already answered my question, so this can be locked now I think.

Sorry if you misunderstood the question, but thanks anyway

Read full topic

item.title: Multiple forums, one database?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

I will try explain this as best i can, this way is very long but it seems to work good enough for me

First, install two one with the prefix smf_ and the second with the prefix smf1_ on the SAME database.
Then go into the second forums file, and go into you’re Sources folder and go into each file and search for
[php]{$db_prefix}members[/php]
and replace with
[php]smf_members[/php]
do that for every file in the sources folder.

That shares the members table, you can do it with other things just do the same but search for
[php]{$db_prefix}tablename[/php]
and replace with
[php]smf_tablename[/php]
some other tables you might want to share is karma so it would be [php]{$db_prefix}karma[/php]
just search around for table names you want to share, pretty simple but takes AGES.

Read full topic

item.title: Multiple forums, one database?
item.dc:creator: @Night26 Night26
item.description:
@Night26 wrote:

I don’t think you would have enough overloading problem in a mysql database. If you were building a proffessional service that requires massive amount of data transfer and requests (more than forums) then you would look into oracle and optimizing the db.

Read full topic

item.title: Multiple forums, one database?
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

OnlyOneRule:

when you installing forms do you usually not get to choose something that goes infront of the table name??

No, SMF asks you for a “Table Prefix”, and tells you not to install two forums in the same Database with the same prefix.

Read full topic

item.title: Multiple forums, one database?
item.dc:creator: @Whitey_b Whitey b
item.description:
@Whitey_b wrote:

I’ve never actually seen an incidence of Having ‘too many’ Forum softwares accessing the database, But In theory you could have unlimited, Its the amount of usage and databse access that would determine how much it can take.

Read full topic
